profiles: Experience Graduate Student Research Assistant Stanford University January 2015  – Present (8 months) I am working on the "Autism Glass Development" project under the supervision of Prof. Dennis Wall. Autism Glass project is a collaboration with psychologists, human-computer interaction experts, and a bioinformatician aimed at studying the efficacy of a wearable device with facial expression recognition technology that delivers feedback to the wearer. In this project , my work has been focused on applying machine learning and computer vision techniques to recognize the facial expressions. The purpose of this project is to build a new tool on Google Glass to help the autistic users to learn these facial expressions on their own instead of using current learning tools. Graduate Student Research Assistant Stanford University School of Medicine September 2014  –  January 2015  (5 months) As a data scientist in VA hospital, my research focused on integrative transcriptomics and epigenomic analysis in neurodegeneration and ageing. In this research, we studied the influence of infusions of blood plasma from young mice on old mice. My collaboration included to combine my computer algorithms knowledge with machine learning techniques to apply computational methods to a hippocampal RNASeq data set and analyze it in terms of gene differential expression. The purpose of this project was to study the corresponding neurophysiological changes in the old mice that may help to find new ways to prevent Alzheimer disease. July 2012  – Present (3 years 2 months) PhD Student, Graduate Student Research Assistant Stanford University September 2005  –  June 2012  (6 years 10 months) Advisor: Professor Roger T. Howe 
Ph.D. Thesis: “A Vacuum Encapsulated Resonator for Humidity Measurement” 
 
• Investigated charge biasing for Micro Electromechanical Systems (MEMS) accelerometers and resonators to reduce power consumption. 
• Designed devices using analytical models and finite element analysis (COMSOL). Drew the layout in CleWin and L-Edit. Fabricated devices in a cleanroom (Stanford Nanofabrication Facility).  
• Created an oscillator: modeled in SPICE, drew PCB layout in KiCAD, and fabricated using surface mount components.  
• Built a custom environmental chamber and wrote its controller in Matlab. 
• Wrote data acquisition and data analysis scripts in Matlab. Used GPIB to communicate with test equipment, including network analyzers, an oscilloscope, a LCR meter, power supplies and a frequency counter  
• Developed analytical electromechanical models in MatLab and Mathematica. Models described the response of a charge biased resonator and surface charging on dielectrics.

Summary Experimental particle physicist by training. Interested in solving challenging problems through research, data analysis, data modeling, simulation, statistics, machine learning, and experiments. 
 
Senior research fellow at Caltech high energy physics (HEP) group. A member of the BABAR collaboration at SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory, and the Mu2e collaboration at Fermilab. 
 
Experience in large data processing and analysis, software development and release management, and particle detector R&D and simulation. Deep understanding of physics and applied mathematics. 
 
Skills 
• Mining of large data sets using machine leaning techniques, data modeling, Monte Carlo simulation, statistical inference, maximum likelihood technique, regression, and hypothesis testing. 
• Computer programming: C/C++, Fortran, Unix shell scripts, Python ([I]Python, Numpy, Scipy, Mat- plotlib, Scikit-learn), HTML. Some experience in Java, R, and MySQL. 
Extensive use of ROOT (a physics data analysis/storage framework) and RooFit (a data modeling/fitting tool), both written in C++ and using C++ as a scripting language (CINT).

Summary Currently working on Salinity Gradient Energy- a new renewable energy source, trying to revolutionize the renewable energy industry. Excited, thereby Working Hard!! 
 
Motivated Engineer looking to contribute to the improvement of Water Quality around the world. Have always dreamt of a world where the tap water in any country is potable. Working on membranes, used to purify water - decreasing costs, increasing efficiency, life, recycling capacity. The Quest for excellent membranes and improved Water Purification technologies has brought me from Chennai, India to Stanford, California. Want to improve my skills in related and allied subjects, gain experience by working for Industries in the same and allied fields. Looking to expand the horizons of my thinking, meet the right people and create solutions for large scale problems in water. Experience Graduate Student Research Assistant Stanford University April 2015  – Present (5 months) Stanford University I find work here to be revolutionary. I am working on economising a relatively new renewable energy source - energy from the salinity gradient between Freshwater and Seawater or 'Blue Energy'​. I am excited about electrochemistry and the optimization of harvesting this energy.  
 
I get to work with greats like Dr. Yi Cui and Dr. Craig Criddle, 'Nature'​ published professors. 
 
Also, for the first time in my life, I get to say, 'Patent Pending'!! Internship University of Calabria May 2014  –  August 2014  (4 months) Reggio Calabria Area, Italy This was one of the best times of my life in the scenic countryside of Italy, also exciting because of Mafia control over the area in which the University of Calabria is located. I spent 4 months in Italy working on the Membrane Distillation process. 
 
According to me, Membrane distillation is a massively underrated technology that can be used for the purification of water. The process though being very easy to understand, implement and realise has not earned much attention because of the economics related to the process. But with new technology, these constraints have been overcome and the advantages of the process completely outweigh its disadvantages. This makes it a very potent technology in the future of water purification and this inspired me to work on it. 
 
In Italy, ITM-CNR is an one of a kind institution which specialises in membranes that are used to filter water for domestic and pollution control purposes. The institute was pioneered by Dr. Enrico Drioli, the world famous Stalwart in Water Purification Technology.  
 
I worked in this institute for four months. My work involved studying and standardizing the Membrane distillation process for the inevitable large scale use of the process in the near future, along with a team of 7 experts. We were able to perform Correlation Analysis between input and output parameters of the process and thereby predict trends in the process' behaviour for changing input conditions.  
 
We were able to standardize and predict the behaviour of the process for Temperature and Pressure changes. A concentration change study was also performed, the data was insufficient to come to a conclusion in the time I was there, but eventually after I finished the internship, the group also standardized the behaviour of the process with changing Concentration of the feed solution. 
 
This experience was both knowledge-rich and abstract, since the group was working on a technology that has not been studied much. Undergrad Student College of Engineering Guindy, Chennai August 2010  –  April 2014  (3 years 9 months) Chennai Area, India Intern Indian Institute of Technology, Madras June 2011  –  March 2014  (2 years 10 months) Chennai Area, India My responsibilities included 
- Casting Flat Sheet Membranes 
- Hollow Fiber Membranes 
- Manufacture of Nanoparticles 
- Characterization of the above particles (charge, size, chemical composition) and subsequent impregnation on the membrane 
- Characterization of membrane characteristics like thickness, pore size, flux rate, bacterial count reduction, efficiency, rejection rate, pore size distribution, mechanical strength, Hydrophilicity and contact angle. Summary As an undergraduate in Civil and Environmental Engineering at UCLA, my focuses were Structural, Geotechnical, and Water Resources Engineering. I interned for a summer in Construction Management at W.E. O'Neil Construction in El Segundo, CA and worked in a UCLA Structural Engineering Lab. I recently completed Stanford University's Environmental Fluid Mechanics and Hydrology Master's program, while acting as a research assistant for Water in the West's California Groundwater Resources visualization project. 
 
In May 2013, I was accepted into the US Navy's Nuclear Propulsion Officer Candidate (NUPOC) program, and started Officer Candidate School (OCS) in January 2014. Unfortunately, I was deemed not physically qualified for Naval service during OCS, as the conditions aggravated asthmatic symptoms, and was honorably discharged. I am currently pursuing a professional engineering certification, and working at Schaaf and Wheeler Consulting Civil Engineers. Experience Assistant Civil Engineer Schaaf and Wheeler April 2014  – Present (1 year 5 months) Santa Clara, CA Providing support on projects including analysis and design of water systems, design of pump stations, stormwater management, storm drain hydraulics, sewer hydraulics, flood control hydrology and hydraulics, and some construction management Nuclear Propulsion Officer Candidate US Navy May 2013  –  April 2014  (1 year) Nuclear Propulsion Officer Candidate collegiate program (to attend nuclear power school and deploy on an aircraft carrier managing nuclear core operations). Started Officer Candidate School in January. Medically disqualified from service after two weeks in training (asthma induced by extremity of climate and environment). While in training, I completed the militarization phase, learning Navy core officer qualities and values, as well as drill routines. I was discharged honorably for medical reasons April 2014. Graduate Student Research Assistant Stanford University April 2013  –  December 2013  (9 months) Water in the West Investigated effects of groundwater pumping/overdraft in California. Specifically, my portion of the project was to study the variety of management types, data collection, and data dissemination in the state to illustrate the heterogeneity of groundwater management in California. Finally, we created conceptual visualizations of findings aimed at lawmakers and other affected parties that were handed over to contractors to build a web application.
